contentrichtext.text: {{italic title}} {{Taxobox | name = Louisiana Quillwort | status = G2 | status_system = TNC | status_ref = <ref name=natureserve>{{Cite web | publisher =NatureServe | title = Isoetes louisianensis | work = NatureServe Explorer | url = http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/servlet/NatureServe?searchName=Isoetes+louisianensis+ | accessdate = 2007-12-19}}</ref> | regnum = [[Plant]]ae | divisio = [[Lycopodiophyta]] | classis = [[Isoetopsida]] | ordo = [[Isoetales]] | familia = [[Isoetaceae]] | genus = ''[[Isoetes]]'' | species = '''''I. louisianensis''''' | binomial = ''Isoetes louisianensis'' | binomial_authority = Thieret }} The '''Louisiana quillwort''' (''Isoetes louisianensis'') is a small, grass-like aquatic plant of the family [[Isoetaceae]]. It is "one of the rarest [[quillwort]]s in North America."<ref name=cpc>[http://www.centerforplantconservation.org/collection/cpc_viewprofile.asp?CPCNum=2345 ''I. louisianensis''.] Center for Plant Conservation.</ref> It occurs in only five locations in [[St. Tammany Parish|St. Tammany]] and [[Washington Parish]]es of [[Louisiana]] and some spots in southern [[Mississippi]] ([[USA]]). It is federally listed as an [[endangered species]], partly due to its highly restricted range.<ref name=fed>USFWS. [http://ecos.fws.gov/docs/federal_register/fr2152.pdf Determination of Endangered Status for the Plant ''Isoetes louisianensis'' (Louisiana Quillwort).] ''Federal Register'' October 28, 1992.</ref> The Louisiana Quillwort occurs predominantly on sand and gravel bars on small to medium-sized streams. These plants live for periods underwater. They are regularly inundated as much as 50 centimeters (20 inches) following rains, and may be inundated for long periods in wet seasons. Its [[habitat (ecology)|habitat]] follows roughly along the [[Bogue Chitto River]]. Associated plants include [[Viola primulifolia|primrose-leafed violet]] (''Viola primulifolia''), [[Scirpus divaricatus|bulrush]] (''Scirpus divaricatus''), [[Justicia lanceolata|water-willow]] (''Justicia lanceolata''), [[Hypoxis leptocarpa|yellow-star grass]] (''Hypoxis leptocarpa''), [[Xyris|yellow-eyed grass]] ''Xyris'' sp. and [[Carex|sedge]] (''Carex'' sp.), [[Nyssa sylvatica|swamp tupelo]] (''Nyssa sylvatica'' var. ''biflora''), [[Nyssa aquatica|water tupelo]] (''Nyssa aquatica''), [[Magnolia virginiana|sweetbay]] (''Magnolia virginiana''), [[Taxodium distichum|bald cypress]] (''Taxodium distichum''), [[Quercus obtusa|swamp laurel oak]] (''Quercus obtusa''), [[Acer rubrum|red maple]] (''Acer rubrum''), [[Pinus taeda|loblolly]] (''Pinus taeda''), [[Cyrilla racemiflora|ti ti]] (''Cyrilla racemiflora''), [[Lyonia lucida|fetterbush]] (''Lyonia lucida''), and [[Ilex verticillata|winterberry]] (''Ilex verticillata'').<ref name=cpc/> Distinctive characteristics of this species include brown-spotted sporangial walls and mega[[spore]]s with highly reticulate ridges, producing a spiny effect. The [[Leaf|leaves]] are up to 40 cm long. The Louisiana quillwort was described recently, in 1973, and was listed as an endangered species in 1992.<ref name=fed/> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=ISLO USDA Plants Profile] [[Category:Isoetes|louisianensis]] [[Category:Lycophyte species]] [[Category:Endangered species]] [[Category:Plants described in 1973]] [[Category:Flora of North America]]
